Description: Discoid weight carved from black mottled green and white hard stone, possibly marble; cylindrical shape, with flat base and top; polished surface; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Discoid weights are not that commonly found in Egypt in general, though they do appear rather conspicuously in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXIII; Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 2, fig. 13 and fig. 26). They are usually of small size and mass like this specimen, and, made out of igneous rock such as basalt, granite and diorite. They do also occur regularly in bronze, notably in the Naukratis collection. The use of marble for this specimen, though attested, is really rare. Discoid weights can be generally associated to the most used standard in Naukratis, the Egyptian standard kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples (Petrie 1926, 14; Cour-Marty 1990, fig. 25). However a lighter unit, around 8g, is also noticed and could correspond to other standards such as the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; van Alfen 2002, 184, n. 654). In the case of this specimen, it could correspond to half of a shekel. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989. Les poids dans l’Égypte ancienne, Vols. 1-3 [unpublished thesis, microform], Paris.
